close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (definition / fields: listen_fd, was_quiesced, itc, options, shutdown, have_new, tid)
explanation:
To determine whether the memset call (and other uses of string.h semantics) in MHD_poll_listen_socket can access beyond object bounds you must reason about the size and indexing of the stack array p and the conditions that drive index increments. The following symbols are required and why:

- struct pollfd
  - Needed to know the size and layout of each array element (sizeof(p) and the per-element storage that memset covers) and to confirm there are no unusual attributes (packing/flexible array) that would change sizeof(p).

- struct MHD_Daemon (definition / fields: listen_fd, was_quiesced, itc, options, shutdown, have_new, tid)
  - The function’s control flow (whether entries are added to p, and how many) depends on these fields. To prove the code never writes p out-of-bounds you must know how these fields are typed and how they are interpreted by the predicates used in the function.

- MHD_socket (typedef)
  - The listen_fd variable ls is of this type; you need its definition to understand comparisons with MHD_INVALID_SOCKET and that no aliasing/size issues change behavior relevant to array indexing.

- MHD_INVALID_SOCKET
  - The check (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != daemon->listen_fd) determines whether the listen FD branch executes (i.e., whether poll_count is incremented). To bound poll_count you must know the semantics/value of this constant.

- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (macro)
  - Controls whether the inter-thread communication FD branch executes and thus whether poll_count can be incremented a second time. Its definition determines when the second array slot is used.

- MHD_itc_r_fd_ (function)
  - Returns the fd stored into p[poll_count].fd when the ITC branch runs. Knowing its signature and return domain helps ensure that using its result as an int fd does not affect array indexing or cause other unexpected behavior.

- MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME (flag)
  - Used in the options test that triggers resume_suspended_connections. Although resume_suspended_connections is called after p has been populated, the options check and any side effects could be relevant when reasoning about daemon state in a full analysis; include the flag to be able to follow that path if needed.

Note: Other callees (resume_suspended_connections, new_connections_list_process_, MHD_accept_connection, MHD_DLOG) do not affect the correctness of the memset invocation directly, but the daemon structure and the two macros/functions above are essential to proving that poll_count never exceeds the declared array bound (2) and that memset(&p, sizeof(p)) covers exactly the allocated object.
